column2: Barclays Inverse US Treasury Composite ETN
column4: Barclays fraud case serves justice lukewarm
column5: LONDON (Reuters Breakingviews) - Britain's graft watchdog is serving up some lukewarm justice. The Serious Fraud Office has charged Barclays and four former employees in connection with the £11.5 billion of capital it raised in 2008 from investors including the Qatari government. The charges of false representation and unlawful financial assistance are the first to have been brought against a major UK bank and its former bosses. In the intervening decade Barclays – and the world – have moved on.

The Serious Fraud Office has charged Barclays and four former employees in connection with the £11.5 billion of capital it raised in 2008 from investors including the Qatari government. column4: Business Watch: For bets on China  not Mexico
column5: Ford said it will move some production of its Focus model to China  suggesting the world's second-largest economy - and not Mexico - could play a much larger role in future vehicle production for North America. Back in January  U.S. President Trump had slammed Ford for shipping small-car manufacturing to Mexico.

column4: Jefferies plods in Morgan Stanley's footsteps
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters Breakingviews) - Jefferies is plodding in Morgan Stanley’s footsteps. Like its bulge-bracket rival  the investment bank run by Richard Handler seems to have steadied its bond-trading business. Its latest earnings  released on Tuesday  also got a boost from underwriting that should bode well for the rest of Wall Street. Morgan Stanley Chief Executive James Gorman  though  has so far done a better job turning progress into profit.

column5: * Shareholders to vote later this month (Adds detail of termination fee  updates share prices)

column4: Rio Tinto starts new exploration in Mongolia's Gobi desert
column5: ULAANBAATAR  June 20 Anglo-Australian miner Rio Tinto  has started new exploration work in Mongolia's Gobi desert after a gap of around five years  in a sign that Mongolia is having some success at bringing back foreign investors.

column4: Glencore says will respond in due course after Rio favors Yancoal bid
column5: LONDON Glencore  on Tuesday said it would review its options after Rio Tinto  said it was sticking to a recommendation of China-backed Yancoal  as the preferred buyer of its Coal & Allied division in Australia.

column4: Glencore says will respond in due course after Rio favours Yancoal bid

column4: U.S. judge faults CFPB 'indifference' toward Sprint settlement
column5: NEW YORK A federal judge on Tuesday faulted the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's apparent "indifference" toward how to distribute money left over from its 2015 settlement with Sprint Corp over unauthorized customer charges.

column4: Russia's UAC targets sales of more than 600 long-range planes
column5: PARIS Russia's United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) said on Tuesday it hoped a long-range  widebody plane it is developing with the Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China (COMAC) would sell more than 600 over a 20-year period.

column4: AIRSHOW-Russia's UAC targets sales of more than 600 long-range planes
column5: PARIS  June 20 Russia's United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) said on Tuesday it hoped a long-range  widebody plane it is developing with the Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China (COMAC) would sell more than 600 over a 20-year period.

column4: AIRSHOW-Russia's UAC targets 2023 test flight for new widebody jet
column5: PARIS  June 20 Russia's United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) is aiming for a first test flight of its long-range widebody jet in 2023 with a view to delivering the first plane two years later  UAC's president said on Tuesday.

column4: With Whole Foods  Amazon on collision course with Wal-Mart
column5: CHICAGO/SAN FRANCISCO When Wal-Mart Stores Inc bought online retailer Jet.com for $3 billion last year  it marked a crucial moment - the world's largest brick-and-mortar retailer  after years of ceding e-commerce leadership to arch rival Amazon  intended to compete. | Video

column4: Whirlpool CEO Fettig to step down  COO Bitzer named as successor
column5: DETROIT Whirlpool Corp   the world's largest maker of home appliances  said on Tuesday that Jeff Fettig will step down on Oct. 1 after 13 years as chief executive and will be replaced by the firm's current chief operating officer  Marc Bitzer.
